comment._content:
This is all of the products, services, etc. that were easy to make out:
Schweppes' Cider; Andrews Liver Salt; Bass; Holidays in the Isle of Man; Carroll's Mick McQuaid Tobacco; Gilbey's Invalid Port; Jam; Think it's a very early Kellogg's ad; Oxo It's 'Meat & Drink' to you; Crosse & Blackwell's Branston Sweet Pickle; Cairnes Ale; For the protection of Floors - Koverflor from Brooks, Thomas & Co.; Palethorpes' Royal Cambridge Sausages; Chivers' Jellies; Cerebos Salt; Dando For Hands, Pots & Pans; Gaiety Theatre, Syncopations, Sunday June 23rd; Theatre Royal Hippodrome; Nestlé's Milk, Richest in Cream; O'Connell's Dublin Ale; Corinthian, None but the Brave; Lasto, the Star Shine; Wrigley's, Smoothes out jangled nerves, 1d per packet; Fruitfield Jams...

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Patrick, in answer to your query the Gardaí did wear those helmets as a relic from the Dublin Metropolitan Police who predated the London Met.  As far as I know they were worn until the general uniform update that took place about 1954.  Up to that time all Gardaí wore a tunic with a stiff collar buttoned up to the neck, a leather belt and a leather case for their baton/truncheon.  The peaked "forage" cap came into use about then in Dublin and the helmets were dispensed with.  In those days there was a distinction between those Gardaí who were based in Dublin and outside.  Those in Dublin were Dublin Metropolitan Gardaí and had a separate run for promotion etc.  Right up to the late 70's the old DMP/DMG register was in use to record the names of all those who served in Dublin!  That is on display in the Garda Museum!

comment.author: 38896199@N06
comment._content:
First of all there were 2,500lbs of Palethorpes Sausages aboard the Titanic! This is from a Black County Article (UK). 

Palethorpes was a name once familiar in households across the country and around the world. The company was founded in the 1850s and by 1896 it boasted that it was the biggest sausage maker in the world, employing hundreds at its model factory in Dudley Port. Its Royal Cambridge sausages were the premier brand and 2,500lbs of them were aboard the Titanic when she sailed on her maiden voyage. The company relocated to Market Drayton in 1967 and is still in business today, as part of Northern Foods, producing sausage rolls, pies and pasties for the likes of Asda and others.

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: Here's an image of the official Catholic Emancipation Centenary badge. It has a brooch style pin on the back so it can be worn as a lapel badge and also a bar through which a ribbon can be hung and this attached to the wearer by means of a safety pin. The ribbon may also be taken down behind the badge and affixed by means of the badge's own pin. www.boards.ie/vbulletin/showthread.php?p=64517688
